entry.title: Starcatching Supernova bookmarking
entry.content:
This is part of a talk I will be giving at BarCampBrighton 7 My attempt at the perfect read-later workflow

I was one of the Delicious refugees of 2011 that ended up making a happy home at pinboard.in. I was pretty rubbish at keeping up with tagging then and still pretty rubbish now, although Pinboard offer a superbly simple UI and cracking bookmarklet that makes light work adding new bookmarks and suggested tags.

Frank Chimero’s excellent talk Oh God, It’s Full of Stars is a fascinating inward look at why we bookmark and what we do that data afterward. Ever since listening to it I’ve been concerned with mastering an automated workflow that adds as much useful sorting/retrieval data to those bookmarks, and, if possible, does something with it meaningful with it too.

Case study: Twitter

I favorite a hell of a lot of Tweets. Twitter don’t provide a decent enough solution to filter them, something only faavorite.com does well. Pinboard has a baked-in Twitter sync that pulls in links from your favorite Tweets. Initially I enabled it but thought there was more data that could be squeezed into the bookmark.

Putting the internet to work for me

If This Then That is an amazing service that bridges the API gap between online services like Pinboard and Twitter and turned out to provide me with exactly the right kind of customization I wanted over my Twitter bookmarks.

There’s a few different reasons why I might want to favorite a Tweet:

  1. URL to interesting resource or article
  2. Memorable or funny quote
  3. Interesting conversation between 2 or more users

So for an ideal bookmark entry it must have:

  1. URL included in the Tweet as the default bookmark URL
  2. URL to the Tweet itself if the Tweet itself is the bookmark and the entire Tweet text
  3. @ Twitter handle of the user

As a bonus, related hashtags auto imported as tags

☆ Twitter ☆ > Pinboard

So I created a recipe that does just that, and more.

Currently, every time I favorite a Tweet the recipe is triggered and I get a bookmark that includes:

  1. Hyperlink to the first URL in the Tweet with it’s page title
  2. Copy of the entire Tweet in the description
  3. Hyperlink to the Twitter user
  4. Hyperlink to the Tweet status
  5. Tagged with custom identifier for filtering all Twitter favorites - ☆twitter☆
  6. Tagged with user’s @ Twitter handle for filtering

This gives me a few options when coming back to retrieve a bookmarked URL, either I have a fair idea who’s Tweeted it or what text was included in the Tweet, both of which can be easily filtered through Pinboard’s powerful search.

I must admit pulling in hashtags as bookmark tags would be a huge advantage and unfortunately the URLs in the Tweet copy remain encrypted in Twitter’s t.co style which is very frustrating.

Even more annoying is that IFTTT now has to shut off most of their Twitter services after Twitter announced their recent API re-write. It’s a huge blow for a whole spectrum of users, one that might have app.net opening their doors wide. They already have IFTTT support so it just need that mass exodus like back in 2011.

A galaxy of Likes

The idea is to apply this method to every site that offers a favorite, Like or do-later operation, trying to squeeze as much additional data into the bookmark and improve the options for retrieval to close the loop.

entry.title: Optimizing Octopress for Instapaper and Twitter
entry.content:
This is part of a talk I will be giving at BarCampBrighton 7 My attempt at the perfect read-later workflow

For a while I’ve been obsessed with nailing a perfect read-later workflow for online publishing. I use Instapaper a lot and do most of my reading, distraction-free, on my 3rd gen. Kindle. I joined IFTTT while in Beta and been using it as the missing link in this workflow. Lastly, my social media of choice is Twitter…for now anyway.

The aim of this workflow is to automate the read-later process as much as possible and document relevant posts for future reference.

Like most services now, Instapaper has a “Like” feature. If I read something that strikes a chord in me, I “Like” it. This is great from an archivist perspective but what else can I do with it? I don’t always have time to compose a Tweet to the author, to be honest I’d rather just open the next article. Besides, the reason I use a Kindle is because I don’t want to be distracted.

☆ Instapaper ☆ > Twitter

So I created this IFTTT recipe to post a Tweet once an Instapaper is “Liked”. I won’t go into how and why I chose to setup the recipe the way I did, I’ll leave that for another blog post coming soon. All I wanted to do is make sure I did something with that data, for me and the author.

I’m pretty sure Instapaper has a Tweet facility baked-in but I prefer to use IFTTT recipes to get a little more customization into that 140-character limit.

My ideal automated Tweet would have:

  1. Custom text
  2. Article title
  3. Article link
  4. Author name
  5. Twitter @ handle
  6. Content related hashtags per post

Using the Instapaper baked-in facility lets you do 2 and 3 easily enough, next up would be visiting the blog url and using a Tweet button and customizing the text, or you could just open up your nearest device and create exactly want you want.

I thought I might be able to at least get the author name from the Instapaper “Liked” RSS feed but apparently not, quite an odd omission for an online/offline read-later service. I had a crack at the Instapaper text parsing, but I must admit I had no idea what I was doing, please Tweet me if you can help me out at all.

So IFTTT can handle 1, 2 and 3 but it seems 4, 5 and 6 have to be hacked together somehow.

A blogging framework for hackers.

Enter Octopress. It’s been a perfect excuse to get started with Github and chance for me to explore the author’s place in this workflow.

Seeing as the Instapaper RSS feed only includes title, link, pubDate and description I decided to include the majority of the Tweet details above in the title of each post. Here’s how I did that.

Add author name and Twitter @ handle

I tried a few different combinations of this before adding a site author in _config.yml

Add content related hashtags per post

I was already using categories so I now precede each entry with an escaped #

GOTCHA ~ this generates without spaces so looks slightly odd in the published urls

Put it all together in the page title

What it looks like in a Tweet

not tweeted yet

Happy, Not Happy

The moment I finally got this together and tested I got the email from IFTTT informing of the closure of some of the Twitter related recipe services. Luckily this recipe is safe as posting content to Twitter is allowed but posting Twitter’s content to another service is not. A lucky escape, for now, although it does break some of my custom workflow that I will need to re-think.
